review_title: Kripalu has drastically changed over the last year
pros:
The food, the grounds...
5 programs sessions a year free
Lots of overtime pay
The emails you get from your superiors, dripping with platitudes and praise, telling you how "grateful" they are, and how much they value you, and your "service".
cons:
CEO
mass terminations
turnover

I have been here 5 years, and watched the place slowly go downhill (for employees, not so much for guests)
In the last year of 2017 things have gotten much worse. 

The first thing the new CEO did was end all Christmas bonuses. She even sent us an email admitting it! Then she had her office remodeled for around 15K. 

They bought $35,000 worth of dune buggy golf carts.
2nd remodel of her office - $$
Removed the picture of Swami Kripalu and put up a "donors plaque". In other words Money is more important than Swami Kripalu's message!

In one year they  fired about 32  long time employees, one of which was very dear to me. They brought in new people, loyal to CEO.

They also changed the rule on more vacation from 5 years to six! perfect timing!!

So many employees have quit or been fired, that we are now forced to work with sub par coworkers,  just to fill out the schedule.

Kripalu needs a union, badly!

Whenever you send a suggestion to upper management they either ignore you, or fail to take action.  

Now they have bought a very expensive new computer system that will bring us more "in line" with Hotels and their "best practices"  It adds more work for the staff and changes all our duties. Kripalu is not a hotel!

pros: Great community of coworkers, great guests, wonderful amenities
cons: hard to make a living, not open

pros: The hope one feels upon winning work in the wellness field, at an organization that is a beacon of acceptance and connected community.
cons:
Yogic vales exploited. Hard work is not rewarded. “We don’t like authenticity” direct quote from a Dean speaking for her colleague, the Chair of the Culture Committee. Raises do not exist. People who do well here are largely supported by family in one way or another. These people leave rather quickly, having more freedom to quit once they see what it’s really like to work there.

Cliques exist, worse than High School. It’s a perpetual popularity contest and echo chamber. My director didn’t know his their/there/they’re rules and cared only for his own career, while crediting his position to his former CEO’s unsolicited mentoring. Technology is painfully stodgy. The cyclical nature of leadership wears out middle-rung employees who need their jobs and don’t rotate out every few months, but rarely get promoted. If someone quits, that just means you have more work because it’s an opportunity to recoup that salary without firing somebody. People are fired because leaders are bad at planning or training new staff well enough so tasks aren’t dropped with turnovers. 
You’re out in the wilderness, but surrounded b affluent people.

pros: The people I worked with were amazing, you are a team and are close knit, its truly a home away from home.  It's the people I worked with that I miss the mostThe aesthetics are beautiful and its enriching to see guests life experiences change while they are there
cons: I was there less than 1 year before I had to leave as a result of retaliation and aggressive behavior from the Senior leadership team and HR. When the new CEO arrived it was a short period of time before everything changed, even the energy in the building became uncomfortable. As a result of numerous layoffs I was forced to take on the work load of 2 other full-time positions (with no pay),  worked remotely on personal time including vacation days to keep up with the work. This is a common theme within the organization to fire key roles & have others pick up the work especially if your salary. And they are very unfair and show favoritism when salaries are considered

review_title: Great place to visit but wouldn't want to work there.
pros: The guests; people from all over the globe come here in search of bettering their lives and the lives of others. The presenters; a wide variety of teachers & programs - program benefits for employees (if your schedule allows) are free or half price. The food; local, organic huge selection of food. (buffet style).
cons: Employees are expected to have a 'give without receiving' attitude. They do not receive raises, even to cover the increase of cost of living each year. Often decisions are made for employees without their input. Overall disconnect between management and staff. Many 'slackers' in management without trustworthy HR leader to confide in to make healthy changes. Top-down imperial thinking - for a company that is supposed to be mission driven - this is disheartening. Little room to grow or move up in the company, unless you're friends with the right people, that will increase your chances.

pros: Glorious Berkshires setting with a destroyed mission.
cons:
There are many current and former employees who feel compelled to review Kripalu and its current situation. During the interview process, many people ask about the Glassdoor and Indeed reviews - they want to know how the last 16 months of reviews remain so horrific. The answer is simple: "Nothing is being done to stop it." The mission, being so "verbally" thoughtful, draws people in to the preliminary conversations / interviews. But once you dive a bit deeper, asking why the reviews are so negatively consistent, listen closely to the answers. Senior leadership is answering in the way they have been instructed and in the way that is consistent with their contracts. Answers are scripted and not honest.

If you Google the senior members, you will become better informed.

Governance is asleep and will remain so until they are obliged to take action. A contract is hard to break and there are many senior contracts in this non-profit.

pros: Organic food, hilltop setting, peaceful views
cons:
Kripalu was by far the most badly managed place I have ever worked.  Leadership is only interested in the spotlight. Deep insecurities permeate conversations and limit any ability to strategize and focus. Members of the administration are pitted against each other and the most cruel treatment is allowed to go unpunished. As a result, the best people resign because they have many options elsewhere. Those who stand up are fired.

Govenance has been asked to step in and will need to at some point. 

Supporters stand in disbelief at the turnover and question their continued association. Many wonder why the story isn't being covered by local and national press. Perhaps a light in the face of this climate will help.

pros:
Leadership - Kripalu continues to evolve and shift to meet the ever-changing needs of its many constituents: guests and employees alike. The leadership has communicated through town halls, emails, and staff events that it cares deeply about the staff and about creating a positive employee culture. They have already implemented fair pay adjustments to increase wages to meet current market rates and have opened up access to the senior executive team for employees to speak candidly about what is important to them. I recently sent a couple requests to have lunch with a couple VPs simply to get to know them better and was warmly received. There are always formal and informal gatherings to meet with staff at all levels. If there is something you want to know, there is no shortage of opportunities to engage with leadership about it. It feels good to be here at the beginning of a wave of positive change.  

Benefits - as a Kripalu employee we have, hands down, the best lunches of any employees anywhere. Our employee discount on meal plans means that I get to eat wholesome, nourishing and delicious meals prepared daily without the stress of bringing lunch to work. We also get to take workshops and trainings to support our individual interests and growth either for free or at a discount. And I try to take advantage of the free yoga classes and amenities available for use before or after work. It is a retreat center after all!

Community - the folks here are a special crew. Most are committed to their work and show up with kindness, self-awareness, and are eager to work together to ensure our work has the greatest positive impact. Getting to know familiar faces and saying hello in the hallways always improves my day. Many of my colleagues have become friends. We find special ways to celebrate birthdays, births, holidays, and even formed a knitting club(!).

Meaningful work - best of all, the work we do here truly matters. We are helping to transform people's lives by teaching them tools to come home to themselves and establish a grounded presence that will help them navigate whatever life brings them. As a retreat center, we provide them space and time to reconnect with themselves and to help them improve their lives and the lives of those in their circles. It is work that makes me proud.
cons: Career advancement - It's clear that though the functional hierarchy at Kripalu makes for effective leadership, it doesn't offer the flexibility needed to grant deserved opportunities for advancement. From recent announcements I understand that this is in review and I strongly believe that this will change in the future.  I hope that it does--both for Kripalu and for the employees who have proven themselves as leaders.

review_title: Run, don’t walk – this is not the place for you…we promise!
pros: Views, nature, healthy food, worthy guests.
cons:
To the person who wrote the review titled “Unknown” please
correct your Overall Rating. You probably meant to put 1 star and not 5
stars.

While it is eye-opening to see the mission of Kripalu dismantled under
the “leadership” of the CEO – the true entertainment reveals itself
while watching the utter scramble of our current Senior Leadership
Team. I know them well and work with them on a daily basis. They are
bailing water from a leaking ship, never knowing where the axe is going
to land next. Kripalu is a nightmare and I mean it when I say, run don’t
walk.

If you want to be bullied, if you want to be verbally abused, work here.
If you want to see your friends and colleagues harassed, work here. If
you want to see guests, faculty, and donors walking away in disgust
then this is the place for you!!! 

Accept a job here and you can’t say you weren’t warned. Let the Glassdoor reviews / ratings, and the CEO’s rating help you turn your back on this very depressing workplace. Kripalu is sinking and no one is more aware than those who work here. This CEO and her “team” abuse, intimidate and malign the staff and now they are turning on each other. In addition, we have an HR
department that has fallen down on the job. But on the positive side –
we, as a staff are united, we are angry, we are documenting and above
all, we are talking!

Kripalu can place a positive review first in the Glassdoor line-up but
people read further. HR writes that they “welcome a deeper
conversation.” Hmmm, how interesting – since confidential
conversations are immediately taken to the CEO (Yes, we have proof).
Betrayal is commonplace (Yes, we have proof). Invasion of privacy is
rampant (Yes, we have proof). “A deeper conversation?” Perhaps
Kripalu should be much less obvious.

pros:
-Employee Assistance Package with price cuts on different insurance
-No smoking on grounds
cons:
-Since it's a non-profit, I thought working here would allow me to be part of something bigger and make real positive change in the world. Apart from my own disappointing employment experience, I'm also disappointed in how much the org keeps moving away from mission-based programming and actions. 
Opportunities seem to go to the few favorites on staff, or external hires. Veteran staff who are good at their job aren't rewarded, mentored, or considered for advancement opportunities. I keep hoping that things will change, but they don't. I feel cheated and this has been the most dis-empowering work experience in over 20 years of full-time employment. Truly saddening as this is meant to be a place for empowerment. A beacon even. The saddest part is that I don't see the underserved or marginalized being supported as a focus, but I do see more catering to the wealthy. 
Paid time off is scant and tricky. This is not aligned with the ideals of wellness that are integral to the mission and vision of a wellness retreat center. This is not a progressive employer. There is a very limited maternity leave and surprisingly no childcare option. 
-No matching 401(K) 
-While responsibilities increase and expectations become more demanding, compensation remains the same.
-Culture and values sound great in theory, but they're not part of the employee experience.

pros: Natural setting with beautiful grounds.
cons:
There is such systemic sadness in this building throughout all levels of the administration. While interviewing I asked about the Glassdoor and Indeed reviews that were so negative - and have now only gotten worse. Being on the inside I will honestly say, what is being reported is absolutely true and unexaggerated. Senior Leadership makes the excuse that only people who are dissatisfied  go to Glassdoor to write their "complaints." That was their answer!  Nothing about taking the reviews seriously or trying to make positive change. At this point, they are having a difficult time getting people to accept positions because the reviews are honest and compelling. No one wants to step into an organization with reviews like this. 

From my perspective,  Senior Leadership, as a body of decision-makers, are puppets who bully at the request of the CEO and EVP.  Many are not suitable hires themselves, so they too are worried that they will be next.  This is perhaps the most vulnerable mess at Kripalu.  They know the secrets of the CEO and they  understand how she operates. They also understand that the Trustees are weak and therefore, no one will step in to rally for Kripalu's well-being and fiscal safety.  With so many holes, it is no wonder that Kripalu is truly failing in every direction.  

As with all places that guide and teach - if you have a fractured administration, you then have fractured faculty and classrooms.  The  guests , faculty and presenters ask me constantly, "What is happening?" Many are disconnecting from Kripalu and going elsewhere.  I supposed it was only a matter of time. 

My advice if you are considering a job here is to walk away. You might think you can avoid being hit, but you can't. This is a "top down" bleed. If the CEO and EVP remain in place it will only get worse, and we already see what has happened oh-so-quickly.  

The Heart of Kripalu no longer exists.  It is a dark and dreary place indeed.
